I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  Report  and  Recommendation  on  a  proposed 
loan to the Kingdom of Tonga for the Economic and Public Sector Reform Program (EPSRP). 
The  Report  also  describes  proposed  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Building  a  Performance-
Based  Public  Service,  and  if  the  proposed  loan  is  approved  by  the  Board,  I,  acting  under  the 
authority delegated to me by the Board, shall approve the TA.  
 

II. 

INTRODUCTION 

2. 
Discussions  between  the  Government  of  the  Kingdom  of  Tonga  and  the  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  on  developing  the  EPSRP  have  been  ongoing  since  1998.  In 
response  to  the  Government's  request  for  TA1  to  formulate  the  proposed  EPSRP,  ADB 
submitted a draft concept paper, including the institutional framework for EPSRP management, 
to the Government in August 1999. The Cabinet of Ministers approved the draft concept paper 
in  April  2000.  The  Prime  Minister  reiterated  the  Government’s  commitment  to  the  reform 
program  in  a  public  statement  made  in  June  2001.  The  TA  to  prepare  the  EPSRP  and  to 
facilitate  the  initial  stage  of  implementation  commenced  in  September  2001.  A  consultation 
mission  was  fielded  during  15-20  October  2001,  and  a  fact-finding  mission  during  24 
November–8 December 2001, followed by a preappraisal mission during 21-26 January 2002.2 
In preparation for the EPSRP, the Cabinet approved  a number of submissions, including all of 
those designated as first tranche conditions, on 23 January 2002.3  
 
3. 
All  reform  measures  have  been  in  preparation  for  an  extended  period  of  1-4  years. 
Moving  forward  now  is  spurred  by  a  number  of  factors—a  worsening  fiscal  situation, 
disappointing  economic  growth,  and  the  eroded  Tonga  Trust  Fund—which  have  led  to    a 
specific  “macroeconomic  moment”  where  macroeconomic  vulnerability  creates  not  just  a  need 
for  borrowing  but  an  increased  understanding  of  the  need  for  reform.  The  Government  has 
taken the initiative to compile these reform measures into a coherent  reform program, and has 
established  an  organizational  structure  and  a  secretariat  to  ensure  its  implementation.    The 
program logical framework (Appendix 1) and the draft policy matrix (Appendix 2) are a result of 
these  efforts  and  were  discussed  with  senior  government  officials,  private  sector 
representatives, and other key stakeholders. Focus group discussions, hearings and workshops 
involving  civil  society  were  organized,  are  still  ongoing,  and  will  continue  during  the 
implementation of the EPSRP. The program logical framework and the policy matrix outline the 
content  of  the  EPSRP,  which  forms  part  of  the  Government’s  overall  reform  program.  The 
comprehensive  policy  agenda  and  reform  priorities  of  the  Government  go  beyond  the  EPSRP 
and are summarized in the development policy letter (DPL) from the minister of finance found in 
Appendix 3.

III. 

THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 

A. 

Background and Recent Economic Performance 

 

  
The  Tongan  economy  grew  at  an  average  annual  rate  of  1.8%  during  1973-1995,  with 
4. 
per capita gross domestic product (GDP) growth at 1.2%. The engine of growth was remittances 
from Tongan workers overseas.4 Real government spending also grew strongly. Real GDP grew 
at an average annual rate of 2.2% in the 7-year period from 30 June 1994 to 30 June 2001; but 
growth rates ranged from - 0.2% (FY1996) to 6.2% (FY2000). The budget statement for FY2002 
observed that the average annual growth for FY1998-FY2000 was estimated at 6.1% in nominal 
terms  and  4.4%  in  real  terms.  This  performance  represents  a  marked  recovery  from  the 
recession over the FY1996-FY1997 period, when minimal growth was recorded. The turnaround 
in FY2000 was attributed largely to growth in the services sector (5.6%) supported by recovery 
in  the  agriculture  and  fishery  sector,  which  grew  by  10.8%.  The  impact  of  millennium 
celebrations was a feature of this period, with a 17.9% growth rate in the commerce, restaurant, 
and  hotel  sectors.  Government  administration  and  community  services  became  the  largest 
sector in the monetary economy by the turn of the 21st  century, growing at an average annual 
rate of 5.0%, and accounting for 15.3% of GDP in FY2001. This sector was a major contributor 
to  growth  through  the  1990s  and  into  the  new  millennium.  Economic  indicators  suggest  that 
GDP growth for FY2001 is likely to be in the order of 6% in nominal terms and 3% in real terms. 
The  anticipated  real  growth  in  GDP  in  FY2002  was  projected  in  June  2001  as  3%  with  some 
potential for improvement.5 
 
 
5. 
However, the forecast for FY2002 was revised downward in December 2001 to 1.5% as 
a  result  of  deteriorating  world  economic  conditions.  The  impact  of  tropical  cyclone  Waka  that 
devastated  the  northern  island  group  of  Vava’u  and  the  Niuas  on  31  December  2001  would 
lower  this  further.  Workers’  remittances  contribute  about  half  of  Tonga’s  foreign  exchange 
earnings, and about 60% of these flows come from thousands of Tongans living in the United 
States.  In  addition,  disruption  to  international  air  services  has  diminished  fresh  fish  exports  to 
Hawaii.  There  will  be  negative  effects  on  government  revenue  as  expenditure  for  imported 
goods  is  affected  by  these  developments.  It  is  also  clear  that  short-term  reform  measures  for 
increasing revenues and reducing expenditures that had been foreseen in June-July 2001 will 
not have much impact in FY2002.  

 

6. 
Government finances deteriorated from a fiscal deficit of 0.2% of GDP in FY1999, to 0.4 
% in FY2000 and 2.6% in FY2001 (Figure 1). The fiscal rule that recurrent expenditure should 
not exceed recurrent revenue was adhered to, but led to a reduction in nonwage expenditures 
to accommodate the increasing wage bill. With the 20% public service wage increase in 2000, 
wages and salaries now account for over 57% of current expenditure, crowding out expenditure 
on other goods and services and limiting the availability of domestic resources for investment. 
Disappointing  collection  of  nontax  revenue,  transfers  to  public  sector  enterprises  (PSEs),  and 
unbudgeted spending, including a loan to the national airline, caused total public expenditure to 
run  ahead  of  budget  estimates  for  FY2002.  In  addition,  there  is  an  estimated  T$30  million 
unfunded liability arising from the public servants’ retirement scheme introduced in 1999. Until 
mid-2001 the Government drew resources from the Tonga Trust Fund6 to cover any emerging

The inflation rate between June 1985 and June 1995 varied around an average of 8.6%.  
As  a  result  of  expansionary  macroeconomic  policies  and  substantial  currency  depreciation, 
drought and cyclone damage, and higher world prices, inflation went from 5.25% in FY2000 to 
7.0%  in  FY2001  and  is  expected  to  grow  above  10%  in  FY2002.  Broad  money  increased  by 
8.3%  in  FY2000  and  by  an  estimated  35.7%  in  FY2001.  The  latter  increase  was  driven  by  a 
35.1% rise in net domestic assets. Net credit to the Government rose more than fivefold in line 
with the financing of the fiscal deficit, and credit to nonfinancial PSEs more than doubled, while 
credit to the private sector grew by around 23.8%. Net foreign assets declined. Monetary policy 
was  tightened  in  early  FY2001  in  response  to  declining  foreign  reserves,  with  the  National 
Reserve Bank of Tonga (NRBT) raising the reserve requirement ratio from 12% to 15% and the 
minimum lending rate from 9% to 12%. The Privy Council also approved credit ceilings in July 
2000. However, monetary policy eased during the latter half of the current FY 2002.

Tonga has enjoyed relatively buoyant growth in recent years at least partly as a result of 
9. 
an  expansionary  fiscal  and  monetary  policy.  However,  the  country  now  faces  balance  of 
payments  difficulties  and  rising  inflation.  Both  of  these  threats  are  serious,  and  neither  is 
susceptible  to  a  short-term  solution.  Even  in  the  face  of  severe  restraint,  foreign  exchange 
reserves  would  take  some  time  to  recover  from  the  current  situation  of  less  than  2  months  of 
import cover to a more comfortable 4-6 months, which was the case in the past. Inflation will put 
further pressure on an overstretched budget. The most immediate of these pressures will likely 
be  for  further  adjustments  to  the  public  service  wage  scale,  which  was  adjusted  upwards  by 
20% in FY2001. Virtually the whole of this increase will have been offset by inflation by the end 
of the current fiscal year. 
 
10. 
It is fair to say that the existence of the Tonga Trust Fund and remittances from Tongan 
overseas  workers  have  masked    economic  reality  in  Tonga  for  a  long  time.  That  reality  is 
sluggish growth, a public sector that is large in relation to the economy, and heavy dependence 
on  the  Government  for  job  creation.  Reform  is  needed  to  address  these  structural  problems 
while remittances still continue to underpin a weak domestic economy. 
 
B. 
 
11. 
At the time of its annual Article IV consultation in June 2001, the International Monetary 
Fund  (IMF)  was  critical  of  the  expansionary  fiscal  and  monetary  policies  pursued  in  FY2001. 
The overall fiscal deficit for FY2001 was then estimated at 2% of GDP and now stands at 1.5%. 
It  was  also  observed  that  despite  a  rise  in  the  reserve  requirement  from  12%  to  15%  in 
September 2000, excess liquidity, coupled with the low interest paid on NRBT short-term bills, 
had facilitated strong credit expansion by banks. IMF prescriptions stressed the importance of 
fiscal  and  monetary  tightening  and  early  implementation  of  corresponding  measures  to  regain 
external viability. 
 
Economic  growth  in  FY2002  is  unlikely  to  come  up  to  expectations  established  before 
12. 
the  events  of  11  September  2001  and  before  the  extent  of  the  world  economic  slowdown 
became evident. Remittances are vulnerable to the shock of possible job losses in the ranks of 
expatriate Tongans.  Imports will decline should there be lower remittances, and consequently 
government  revenues,  which  are  largely  import  related,  will  fall.  Exports  of  niche  agricultural

(i) 

 

 

 

The Government has been active in almost every field of economic endeavor. In 
addition  to  public  utilities,  communications,  and  transportation  (both  marine  and

aspects  of  economic  life  that  are  not  normally  regarded  as  traditional  areas  of

(ii) 

The Government has become the largest employer by far, with nearly 5,000 paid 
positions accounting for over one third of total paid employment. Employment in 
PSEs  adds  nearly  another  2,000  employees  and  raises  the  total  government

operating costs so that the relatively large government labor force is not provided

clearly needed.

The current tax system in Tonga relies heavily on foreign trade taxes, particularly those 
on imports.18 It is affected by an extensive array of exemptions, allowances, and loopholes that 
result in inequities and inefficiency in tax administration.19 The income tax base is narrow, and 
the whole taxation system has become regressive. To stimulate the growth of the private sector 
and spread the tax burden across the community, it is proposed to shift the emphasis of taxes 
from  “trade  taxes”  (namely  ports  and  services  tax  and  import  duties),  to  a  limited  domestic 
consumption  tax.    This  tax  would  be  collected  primarily  at  the  import  stage  and,  with  larger 
businesses, at the point of sale of imported or locally produced goods and services.  Coupled to 
this  would  be  a  reworking  of  individual  and  corporate  income  taxes  to  provide  a  fairer  system 
with  generally  lower  rates  of  tax  and  the  abolition  of  the  ports  and  services  tax.  PFTAC  has 
assisted  the  Government  in  the  preparation  of  this  new  taxation  system.  A  cabinet  paper  with 
specific recommendations on tax changes was  discussed by the Cabinet on 23 January 2002 
and resulted in its approval to undertake wider consultations on the proposed tax reform and to 
draft  legislation.  The  Government  is  also  in  the  process  of  reviewing  the  tariff  system  in  the 
context of the planned accession to the WTO. However, the EPSRP includes improvements in 
the  current  tax  administration  (para.  35),  as  they  are  necessary  to  achieve  fiscal  balance  and 
are  a  precondition  for  the  new  tax  regime.  The  introduction  of  the  new  tax  regime  itself  is

B. 
 
76. 
Political authority is highly centralized  in the King and the Cabinet, and the Government 
exerts a high degree of control over the economy.  The successful implementation of reform will 
require  considerable  and  sustained  political  will  to  (i)  delegate  an  increased  share  of 
management  responsibilities  to  government  departments  within  the  reform  framework;  and  (ii)  
create a transparent, consistent, and responsive policy environment. To date, such risks have 
been mitigated by the strong commitment of most senior government officials to push through 
the key policy reforms.  The Government’s establishment of a public-private sector consultative 
committee in 1998 was an acknowledgement of the importance of increased public participation 
in the decision-making process. Reform measures have been in preparation for some time, but 
until  recently  have  not  been  acted  upon  by  the  Cabinet.  Hence,  they  have  not  been  placed 
before the Privy Council and the Parliament. The reform program is strongly supported by the 
Privy  Council.  The  Prime  Minister  and  the  minister  of  finance,  both  appointed  with  the 
endorsement  of  the  Privy  Council,  were  selected  because  of  their  recognized  commitment  to 
reform.  Over the past 2 years, the Privy Council has also approved several policy measures to 
improve the governance of PSEs and to lay the groundwork for corporatization and privatization.  
These  developments  indicate  that  the  proposed  reforms  are  supported  by  the  highest 
authorities in the country. 
 
77. 
For  the  first  time,  Tonga  is  confronted  with  a  situation  that  leaves  the  Government  no 
option but to reform. The fast-deteriorating fiscal situation, the disappointing economic growth—
after  the  devastation  caused  by  tropical  cyclone  Waka,  GDP  growth  is  now  estimated  to  be 
below  1.5%—and,  most  critical,  the  disappearance  of  the  safety  net,  the  eroded  Tonga  Trust 
Fund,  have  together    shaped  the  necessary  specific  “macroeconomic  moment”  where 
macroeconomic  vulnerability  has  generated  broad-based  commitment  to  reform.    The 
Parliament  is  fully  aware  of  this  situation  and  is  expected  to  fully  support  the  proposed 
legislative reforms.

B. 

Socioeconomic Context 

2. 
Population.  The  1996  census  recorded  a  population  of  97,784.  The  total  fertility  rate 
was calculated at 4.2%, which, although high, has been offset by high emigration rates since the 
1970s; thus the average annual population growth rate since 1986 is low at 0.3% per annum. 
The  number  of  Tongans  living  overseas  was  estimated  to  be  between  35,000-45,000  in  1993 
and may now be considerably higher.2  
 
3. 
Urbanization.  There  has  been  a  massive  shift  from  an  agricultural  subsistence-based 
economy to  substantial dependence on emigration, remittances, and public sector employment 
combined  with  increased  urbanization.  Sixty-eight  percent  of  the  population  of  Tongatapu,  the 
most  populous  island  in  the  group,  live  in  the  urban  area  of  Nuku’alofa,  and  villages  on  the 
island  are  developing  increasingly  suburban  characteristics.    The  Government  has  recognized 
urban  growth  as  an  issue  of  concern  since  1966,  putting  pressure  on  national  resources  for 
increased expenditure on physical infrastructure. Efforts continue to distribute services equitably 
between  the  rural  and  urban  population.  The  provision  of  high  schools  in  the  outer  islands  
(Ha’api group, Vava’u, Niuataputopu, and Niuafo’ou) aims to discourage rural-urban migration.  
 
4. 
Despite extensive socioeconomic changes over the past 30 years, Tongan customs and 
traditions, the monarchy, the churches, and the extended family continue to be respected and 
emphasized and are all interconnected.  
 
 
5. 
Human  Development.  The  United  Nations  Development  Programme  (UNDP)  human 
development index ranks Tonga sixth out of 14 Pacific Island states.3 On a global scale Tonga 
is  ranked  107.  Tonga’s  relatively  high  ranking  arises  from  its  social  achievements  in  the 
provision  of  universal  primary  education,  public  health  services,  water,  and  sanitation,  which 
have produced an almost universally literate population with average life expectancy of 67 years

7. 
There  is  significant  legal  discrimination  against  women  with  regard  to  property  rights. 
Very  few  women  have  direct  rights  to  own  land,  due  to  a  patrilineal  system  of  land  allocation 
and inheritance adopted in the 19th century. Further, women are not permitted to legally register 
land in their own names.4 This affects women’s access to credit, as significant assets tend to be 
registered in the names of men.5 Indicative recent surveys6 suggest that more men than women 
in economically active age groups migrate. Accordingly women-headed households (19%  of all 
households in 1996) constitute a vulnerable group. There is concern that if the law gave every 
woman equal rights of inheritance with her brothers, control of portions of land might pass from 
the  control  of  her  own  family  and  come  under  the  control  of  her  husband’s  family.  Although 
kainga  (extended  families)  count  both  males  and  females  as  members  by  birth,  and  accord 
special respect to sisters and members of the female descent line, the control of family property 
is patrilineal. This fact has some influence on family decisions about educational investment in 
favor  of  males,  although  it  is  offset  by  the  fact  that  families  tend  to  invest  in  children  who 
achieve well, irrespective of their gender.  
 
8. 
Poverty. Among ADB’s 12 PDMCs, Tonga ranks first in the human poverty index. There 
are no recent household income and expenditure data on which firm conclusions about poverty 
can  be  based.7  In  line  with  ADB’s  new  policy  on  poverty  reduction,  a  preliminary  poverty 
assessment  was  carried  out  under  a  regional  technical  assistance.8  The  initial  findings  were 
compiled and circulated to the Government for comments. Additional data will be gathered for 
further  assessment  of  the  poverty  situation  in  Tonga  through  a  small-scale  TA,9  which  was 
approved in 2000, to assist the Government in conducting a household income and expenditure 
survey. The poor, in terms of national relativity, are those who suffer “poverty of opportunity” in 
relation  to  employment  and  other  chances  to  improve  their  standards  of  living,  particularly  the 
youthful  majority.  Many  Tongans  live  in  overcrowded,  poor-quality  houses,  in  conditions 
conducive to social stress.

Assessing the Impact of Reforms under the EPSRP 

23. 
The EPSRP envisages (i) continuation of the existing freeze on new appointments to the 
public  service,  (ii)  enforcement  of  the  retirement  age  of  60,  and  (iii)  provision  of  lump  sum 
incentive  payments  to  encourage  employees  over  50  to  take  early  retirement.  Currently,  79 
public  servants  in  established  posts  are  over  60  years,  and  516  are  over  50  years  of  age.16 
Public  service  regulations  require  retirement  at  age  60,  but  the  rule  is  not  enforced.  It  is  not 
known how many government workers employed on a daily basis (752 in all) are in these age 
groups.  Under  the  EPSRP,  those  positions  that  have  been  filled  for  long  periods  of  time  by 
employees on a daily basis will be established, so that the employees holding the posts will be 
entitled to pensions and early retirement benefits if they are in the eligible age groups.  
 
24. 
A retirement fund for public servants covers workers in the public sector. Under the old 
pension scheme, employees had the option of retiring with a pension or a lump sum. The new 
scheme only provides lump sum payments. The Government has a liability of about T$30 million 
to the pension fund, which might constrain its ability to meet a sudden increase in demand for 
lump sum payments, as would occur if it rapidly downsized in the public service. Loan proceeds 
have been specially earmarked to cover retirement benefits and compensation payments.

Background and Rationale 

A. 
 
A  major  part  of  the  Government’s  policy  reform  program  is  the  initiative  to  build  a

service while maintaining and improving service delivery. Its successful implementation is crucial 
to  fiscal  balance,  improved  governance,  and  effective  economic  policy  reform.  The  Prime
